body:
Thank you for taking the time to read and reply to my comment.  
Words can’t express the gratitude I have for all the staff from start to finish. Sadly, I didn’t get all the staff members names. Here is a few I did get.  
Amy cared for me in the assessment and theatre. Amy was very knowledgeable and reduced my fears of having a section. Aswell as reducing my husbands anxiety over the whole process. Amy kept my husband and myself reassured when our baby needed some assistance when she came into the world. Amy was also able to help my husband feed baby while I was being sutured and struggling to breast feed.  
Jenny and Margaret were 2 midwives of many that cared for me and baby on the ward, they took the time to get to know me and my husband, Margaret especially. Margaret was a bucketful of knowledge and took the time to chat when she wasn’t attending to the other mothers. Chat does the mental health some good especially with covid restrictions still in place which prevents relatives other than partners from coming in.  
There was 2 midwifery students who will be fantastic as midwives when they qualify, their names were Rebecca and Natasha. No question was silly and they took the time to show and explain things.  
I know time is an issue in the NHS as workload increases with more paperwork and short staff but no staff member made this known and always tried to help all the mothers and babies. All staff went above and beyond for all.

signature: Tierna Armstrong, Head of Day & Residential Care, Older People's Division, Southern Health & Social Care Trust
body:
Thank you for sharing your positive comments I will pass these on to the Manager the Cloughreagh Team and the wider multi -disciplinary community team  
Thank you for sharing what is important for you and what you noticed during your stay about Name Badges. I agree with you its very important that we all identify ourselves to those we are providing care for and talking with This is particularly important as you have highlighted when wearing face masks as often everyone looks the same especially when also wearing similar uniforms.  
The simple act of knowing the name of staff member can help form a better bond, create a personal connection, and reduce stress. We also know that a name badge enables a better understanding of the staff members area of specialty and helps our residents know what questions to ask if they want to share something or have a query or a problem  
It is important that or staff all introduce themselves properly and wearing a name badge improves interaction and recall of who who you have been talking too.  
Your story has been very important for us to hear and share. I will be reviewing the importance of wearing name badges not just in Cloughreagh but across all the services in my line of responsibility and with other colleagues.  
regards, Tierna Armstrong

signature: Andrew Cassidy, Patient Experience Officer, Patient Experience, NHS 24
body:
Dear Someone12,  
Thank you for sharing your story on Care Opinion. I was sorry to read that you experienced such a lengthy asthma attack. This would have been a worrying time for you, and I hope you are now well on the road to recovery. I was pleased to read that the emergency doctor you saw was able to provide you with the medication that you needed.  
My team manages feedback relating to NHS 24 services, and I was pleased to read that you found the call to 111 helpful. I was sorry to read that you subsequently tested positive for COVID-19 and I hope that you are now feeling much better.  
I was sorry to read of the issues that you experienced in trying to obtain a prescription, and I am sure that my colleagues from NHS Lothian will be keen to address your feedback.  
I would like to be able to share your positive feedback with the staff who managed your call to NHS 24. To allow me to do this, I would be grateful if you would contact me directly at patient.experience@nhs24.scot.nhs.uk and provide me with your name, date of birth, and the date and approximate time of your call to 111. This will allow me to identify the staff member or members who managed your call and share your kind words with them. I would be grateful if you would include your Care Opinion user name in any correspondence.  
Thank you for taking the time to share your story with us. Once again, I hope that you are well on the way to recovery.  
With best wishes,  
Andrew

body:
Dear Malley,  
Thank you for sharing your story on Care Opinion, and for contacting my colleague, Shona, to provide her with the further detail she requested in her response. I was very sorry to read of the challenges you have experienced and wish you well.  
I would also like to thank you for sharing full details of your experience with colleagues from NHS Ayrshire and Arran. I can confirm that they have shared your feedback with my team. In order to provide you with a single response detailing the care you received from both Boards, I will be pleased to provide NHS Ayrshire and Arran with a contribution to their response answering the specific points you raise pertaining to your attempts to contact NHS 24. I have raised the issue of your calls disconnecting with our Technical Infrastructure Team and requested that they review your interactions with NHS 24. I look forward to sharing the outcome of their investigation with you.  
I appreciate that this has been a difficult experience for you, and would like to thank you again for taking the time to share your valuable feedback with us. Should you have any questions in the meantime, please do not hesitate to contact our Patient Experience Team at patient.experience@nhs24.scot.nhs.uk  
With best wishes,  
Andrew

signature: Portishead Medical Group
body:
Dear Pauline
I apologise for your experience. In response to feedback regarding patients calling and hearing the engaged tone we have recently changed our phone system to one that allows calls to queue on 'the cloud'. It is still early days for this system and we are working through a few issues - we hope these will be resolved soon. Please be assured that we have appointments to book every day and a dedicated urgent team to see patients whose problem is too urgent to wait until another day. You may also like to try booking appointments online - you can register for this on the NHS App or our reception team can provide log in details for you.
Kath Payne

signature: Beacon Medical Group
body:
Thank you for taking the time to provide Beacon Medical Group with your feedback. We appreciate you doing this. 
I am sorry to learn that your customer service has fallen below the standards that you would expect and would like to apologise for this.
We have been experiencing high call volumes and for the period from January to April 2022 we received an average of 778 calls a day. Mondays are usually our busiest day and our busiest time of the day is 11am, except on a Monday, which is at 8am, with an average rate of 196 calls an hour.
I can advise that the average waiting time for our calls is 10 minutes 51 seconds and this is an improvement from an average of 14 minutes waiting time in October 2021.
Beacon Medical Group introduced the total triage system in November 2019 and patients can contact us using our online services such as eConsult. Depending in the urgency of the patients’ medical concerns, patients will usually be contacted by telephone or video consultation within 48 hours of receipt of their eConsult. Face to face appointments are often not required and only made where the GP makes the decision that this is needed.
Any queries about your medication will be looked into and you will be contacted to discuss this further.
Thank you
Caroline Hayward
Patient Liaison and Communications Lead
Beacon Medical Group

signature: Andrew Cassidy, Patient Experience Officer, Patient Experience, NHS 24
body:
Dear Treesparrow,  
Thank you for sharing your story on Care Opinion. I was sorry to read that you had been bitten by a cat - I have a deep fondness for cats, but I appreciate they can have a mind of their own at times! I hope you weren't too badly injured and are recovering well.  
I was pleased to read that your care, from calling 111 to being seen at the QEUH, was handled so quickly and efficiently. I'm sure my colleagues from NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde will be equally pleased to read your positive feedback.  
If you have any specific feedback relating to your experience of calling NHS 24, I would be pleased to share it with the staff who were involved in managing your call. You can contact me directly at patient.experience@nhs24.scot.nhs.uk - I would be grateful if you would include your name, date of birth, and the date of your call in any correspondence. This will allow me to share your feedback directly with the staff who handled your contact with the service.  
Thank you once again for sharing your feedback with us. It really is such a boost for our staff to read such positive stories. I do hope you are recovering well.  
With best wishes,  
Andrew

signature: Claire Richards, Lead Nurse, Pre Op Assessment, Royal Cornwall Hospitals NHS Trust
body:
Dear michell982@aol.com,  
Thank you for taking the time to share your story with us.  
I am not sure whether your anaesthetic pre assessment was done in my Central Pre-Assessment department or by the as they do some of their own assessments that Central Pre-Assessment are not involved in.  
We do our best to accommodate patient wishes about timings of appointments. I will check with our Bookers that our clinic letter appointments are set up to match appointment times, as I can't explain why you would be told one time and be given a letter for a different time. Please accept my apologies for being called at a time other than you were expecting. I hope that the nurse checked with you that it was convenient for you, and you weren't made to feel obliged to proceed at that time.  
I am not aware that any of my nurses have hearing difficulties that affect them on the telephone, but I will raise your comments with the whole team and address what we find.  
The purpose of the pre assessment is to both help you and the clinical teams to prepare for an anaesthetic. By establishing whether someone has any mental health needs before they come into hospital takes away the need to check again on the day of surgery. We intentionally ask this question generically as we must respect that some people do not like the intrusion whereas others are very keen to share details in the knowledge it will make their admission easier. If people share details, we can ask further questions to provide appropriate care for them on admission. I am sorry that you felt we were intrusive.  
Your comments don't say the length of time Pre-Assessment advised you would have to wait post op before being discharged. This would vary according to if you had your procedure in the Oral Surgery Day Unit or Newlyn theatre and what type of anaesthetic you had or whether you had local anaesthetic and sedation, and whether you knew your place of admission at the time of the telephone assessment as well as many other factors including where you were placed on the operating list, staffing on the day of surgery and how you recover. Essentially what I am trying to explain is that at the time of assessment it can be difficult to predict this and please accept our apologies for getting it wrong for you.  
Regarding eating after dental extraction, we would encourage patients to speak to the Oral Surgery team at the time of admission. The anaesthetic assessment nurse maybe should have directed you to the Oral Surgery team for specific advice about eating and I will ask that they do so in future.  
Pre-Assessment nurses are educated in preparing people for an anaesthetic rather than the fine detail of individual surgeries and individual surgeons. I always encourage pre assessment nurses to direct patients to the relevant surgical team for specific questions which I will reiterate to the team following your feedback.  
Thank you for your feedback I hope I have been the correct team to answer your queries and some of the rationale for our action makes sense.  
Claire Richards

signature: Andrew Cassidy, Patient Experience Officer, Patient Experience, NHS 24
body:
Dear Hip Patient,  
Thank you for sharing your story on Care Opinion. I was sorry to read that you had been so acutely unwell, and hope that you are now well on the way to recovery,  
I was delighted to read your generous feedback - it sounds like everyone involved in your care, from the Call Handlers at NHS 24 to colleagues at Stobhill Out of Hours and the QEUH looked after you every step of the way. It's always such a pleasure to read stories like yours, where emergency situations are made much more manageable by expert staff. I'm sure my colleagues at NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde will be equally pleased to read your story.  
If you would like to provide me with your details, I would be pleased to share your feedback with the staff at NHS 24 who managed your call. If you would like to contact me, you can email me at patient.experience@nhs24.scot.nhs.uk - please provide your name, date of birth, the date of your call, and your Care Opinion user name. This will allow me to identify the staff who looked after you and share your feedback with them.  
While it sounds as though you have been through quite a difficult time, I'm pleased to read that your overall opinion of the care you received was amazing - reading your story has certainly brightened my afternoon, and I will be delighted to share your positive story with my wider team.  
I wish you all the very best for your ongoing recovery, and would like to thank you again for taking the time to provide such valuable and positive feedback.  
With best wishes,  
Andrew

signature: Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham
body:
Dear Sabah 

Thank you so much for taking the time to provide feedback about the Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham. We are delighted to hear that you felt that the majority of your stay was a positive one. 

If you would like to provide any further feedback about your experience please visit the hospital webpage www.uhb.nhs.uk/yourviews. 

On the other hand we are sorry to hear that there were some negative aspects. Regarding visiting - the trust is taking a careful approach to re-opening visiting as we still have Covid-positive patients on the wards. Regarding entertainment - you are correct that access to TVs has sadly been discontinued - however there should be access to activity books and tablets on every ward and the Patient Experience Team will contact the department to facilitate extra supplies of these if required. 

We are keen to listen to your concerns in more detail to understand more about what has happened and to try to resolve your outstanding concerns. If you are happy to do this please make contact with the Patient Advice and Liaison Service (PALS) to provide your details. PALS are here to help and can be contacted by phone 0121 424 0808, by email PALS@uhb.nhs.uk or by contact form at https://www.uhb.nhs.uk/forms/contact-complaint-concern 


Best Wishes

James Cunningham

signature: Central Medical Centre
body:
Dear Jeff

Thank you for your feedback regarding your recent contact with the surgery and for taking the time to speak with me earlier today to discuss your experience in more detail.

From our discussion it would appear that there was a problem with the communication technology when our clinician tried to contact you on Monday as your experience differs to that which is recorded on our systems.  

We were unaware that you had experienced a problem until we received notification that you had posted your feedback online.  Once we became aware that there had been a problem we responded by arranging another appointment for you.  

I am pleased to hear that you have now had a telephone consultation with one of our clinical team who has been able to address your problem and help you.

body:
Dear Patient, thank you for your feedback and I would like to apologise for the distress caused to you. We follow our 48 hours prescription policy.  Unless it is necessary for the GP to do medication review or discuss with the patient before issuing further dose.
For test results doctors send message to the patient after they have reviewed them. In the message to the patient they clearly state the time scale the patient needs to book an appointment and that depends on the significant abnormality of the results. 
The reason for specifying a time scale for results is to balance GP access for the patients. If you wish to discuss this further please do not hesitate to contact me.

signature: John Kerr, Emergency Nurse Practitioner SWAH ED, Acute Services Emergency Care, WHSCT
body:
Dear Mercat  
Thank you for taking time out to use the Care Opinion platform to voice your concerns about your recent visit to our department. I am sorry to hear it was an unsatisfactory experience. In light of this, I would like to address each of your concerns individually.  
1. On your journey through the Emergency department, you will, as a patient, encounter many staff from medical, administrative and auxiliary backgrounds. Children are one of the most vulnerable groups to attend our department, and for this reason, it is often necessary to question appropriately and regularly, in order to safeguard the child. I appreciate this may seem frustrating to you, however, the protection and welfare of the child is our paramount concern at all times.  
2. Patients present to our department with a multitude of complaints and ailments. Some of these will require the patient to remain fasting, to abstain from eating and drinking. This may have been a factor in why patients did not receive a drink, when requested.  
3. I am sorry to hear that your child did not not receive adequate pain relief while in the department. This is unacceptable and for that I apologise. I do not have access to the medical notes, and I cannot confirm whether or not your child had pre hospital medication. Calpol has a dosing regime of every 4 to 6 hours, and this may have been a factor in the delay.  
I am sorry that you were placed in a corridor with adults. Unfortunately, we work with the resources available to us, however, we try to accommodate children and their parents as best we can. Sometimes at high demand periods this is not always possible to achieve.  
We do have a referral pathway for paediatrics to the ward in place, agreed with both departments. A recent complaint on this platform identified a failure, and an action plan was identified and put in place. With a large number of staff working within the department, it can take time to filter through to all concerned. I am sorry that we have failed you and your child on this occasion, and for that I do apologise.  
Finally, I hope that you and your child are well, and your little one has made a complete recovery.  
kind regards  
john kerr
